document.docTitle: Revision of Neacomys spinosus (Thomas, 1882) (Rodentia: Cricetidae) with emphasis on Peruvian populations and the description of a new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of Neacomys spinosus (Thomas, 1882) (Rodentia: Cricetidae) with emphasis on Peruvian populations and the description of a new species

emphasis.docTitle:
Revision of
Neacomys spinosus ( Thomas, 1882 )
( Rodentia : Cricetidae ) with emphasis on Peruvian populations and the description of a new species

subSection.paragraph: NATALI HURTADO1,2,4 & VÍCTOR PACHECO 2, 3

paragraph.emphasis: Doctorado en Ciencias, mención Ecología y Evolución, Universidad Austral de Chile , Campus Isla s/n, Ƒaldivia, Chile . E-mail: natalihm@gmail.com.
Departamento de Mastozoología, Museo de Historia Natural de la Universidad Nacional Mayor de San Marcos. Av. Arenales 1256, Lima 14, Lima , Peru .
Instituto de Ciencias Biológicas “Antonio Raimondi”, Facultad de Ciencias Biológicas, Universidad Nacional Mayor de San Marcos. Av. Arenales 1256, Lima , Peru . Lima 14.

subSection.paragraph:
The large spiny mouse
Neacomys spinosus ( Thomas, 1882 )
has been considered the widest ranging species of the genus, occurring in southern Colombia , eastern Peru , western Brazil and northern Bolivia . The morphological variation between subspecies and populations of
N. spinosus
has been noted; nonetheless, this variation has not been assessed in a morphological or molecular context. Here, we present a taxonomic revision of
Neacomys spinosus
s.l. using qualitative and quantitative morphological analyses. These analyses were complemented with molecular analysis to reconstruct the phylogenetic relationships among species of
Neacomys
, based on sequences of the cytochrome b gene. Our results reveal that
N. spinosus
s.l. is a monophyletic group, and morphological and molecular evidence to differentiate three taxa:
N. spinosus
s.s. , an endemic species from mountain cloud forests in Peru ;
N. amoenus
s.l. from the Cerrado between Bolivia and Brazil to the Amazonia between Ecuador and northern Peru , and
Neacomys
sp. nov. from mountain cloud forests from southern Peru to Bolivia . Also, our molecular results indicate that
Neacomys
is still far from being completely known. For instance, there are three candidate species pending of taxonomic revision. Finally, we propose three species groups within
Neacomys
: “
paracou
”, “
tenuipes
” and “
spinosus
”, and discuss biogeographical scenarios of the genus within South America.
Keywords: Bolivia , Peru , spiny mouse, Oryzomyini , Andean rivers

Spiny mice of the genus
Neacomys Thomas, 1900
are small oryzomyines that externally present grooved spine hairs, reddish to dark brown dorsal fur, contrasting pale ventral fur, a long tail, and large hind feet (
Patton et al. 2000
;
Voss et al . 2001
). This genus is distributed from
Panama
to northern Bolivia , inhabiting Central American and Amazonian lowlands as well as highlands of montane rainforests of the eastern slope of the Andes in South America (
Patton et al. 2000
; Weksler & Bonvicino 2015a ).
Neacomys
is currently recognized as a monophyletic group (
Patton et al. 2000
; Weksler 2006 ; Catzeflis & Tilak 2009 ), composed of eight species ( Weksler & Bonvicino 2015a ). Some evidence, however, suggests that
Neacomys
could have a greater diversity than what has currently been documented for this genus (
Patton et al. 2000
; Catzeflis & Tilak 2009 ; Hice & Velazco 2012 ; da Silva et al. 2015).

Recent studies of the systematics and phylogeography of
Neacomys
have revealed undiscovered diversity in this genus. For instance,
Patton et al. (2000)
described two new species based on morphological and molecular analyses of
Neacomys
from the Juruá River basin. These analyses indicated that the other Amazonian populations are molecularly differentiated from Juruá populations as candidate species level. Although the authors suggested that these candidate species could be named
N. amoenus Thomas, 1903
or
N. carceleni Hershkovitz 1940
, which are current junior synonyms of
N. spinosus
, these taxa are pending of a taxonomic review. Similarly, Voss et al.

(2001) described two new species based on the morphological revision of populations of
N. guianae Thomas, 1905
from the Guyana Region.
Patterson et al. (2006)
reported a new species (currently in description; Patterson, in litt.) from the Paucartambo region ( Cusco ) that could be related to
N. musseri
or
N. minutus
. Using molecular data, Catzeflis & Tilak (2009) reported a new candidate species from the Amazonas state of Brazil . While Hice & Velazco (2012) distinguished a candidate species from the western Amazonas basin using morphological data and morphometrics, but it lacks of formal description. All this evidence indicates that the real taxonomic composition of
Neacomys
has been underestimated, however, more revisions are needed to delineate the taxonomy and distributions of the species.

Within
Neacomys
,
N. spinosus
has the widest distribution, from southern Colombia to northern Bolivia and western Brazil . It inhabits the altitudinal gradient present between Amazonia and the Andes spanning Montane, Pre-Montane, and Rain Forests (
Pacheco et al. 2009
;
Pacheco et al. 2011
) from 300 to 1900 m in elevation ( Leo & Romo 1992 ;
Patton et al. 2000
; Weksler & Bonvicino 2015a ). This species exhibits great morphological variation; for instance, color of dorsal fur varies from reddish to brown (
Patton et al. 2000
; Weksler & Bonvicino 2015a ), ventral fur can be from totally white to grayish ( Thomas 1882 ; Lawrence 1941 ; Weksler 2006 ), tail can be longer than head-body length or they can be same sized ( Lawrence 1941 ), metatarsal patch ranges from being a small tenuous spot to broadly extended ( Lawrence 1941 ), hind feet being smaller in lowland populations than in highland populations ( Lawrence 1941 ), and supraorbital beads of the skull range from moderately developed to strongly developed ( Thomas 1882 ; Lawrence 1941 ).

Taxonomically, four subspecies have been recognized within
N. spinosus
( Thomas 1900 ; Thomas 1903 ; Hershkovitz 1940 ; Lawrence 1941 ): N. s.
tenuipes Thomas, 1900
is found in northern Colombia and is distinguished from
spinosus
because it presents darker dorsal fur, pure white ventral fur, and shorter and more slender hind feet ( Thomas 1900 );
N. s. amoenus
inhabits Brazilian Cerrado, it is larger than
spinosus
, has a longer tail and braincase, softer and shorter dorsal and ventral fur, and pure white ventral fur ( Thomas 1903 );
N. s. carceleni
is found near the Curaray River in Ecuador and differs from
spinosus
because it has a shorter tail, pure white ventral fur, a longer and heavier braincase, well developed supraorbital ridges, and longer molar rows ( Hershkovitz 1940 ); and
N. s. spinosus
inhabits along montane cloud forests in Peru , that presents ventral fur with gray bases and large metatarsal patches ( Thomas 1882 , Lawrence 1941 ). From these subspecies, based on morphological characters alone, Lawrence (1941) considered
N. tenuipes
to be a species, retained
N. s. spinosus
and
N. s. carceleni
as subspecies, but dismissed
N. s. amoenus
from the comparisons entirely.
N. tenuipes
is molecularly distinct from other congeners, the support of its phylogenetic relationships among
Neacomys
is weak although is supposed to be closer related to Amazonian species (
Patton et al. 2000
). On the other hand, based on a bibliographic review, Cabrera (1961) recognized three subspecies, that differ each other in their geographical distributions
N. s. spinosus
,
N. s. amoenus
, and
N. s. carceleni
. Currently,
N. spinosus
with its subspecies
amoenus
and
carceleni
is considered as widely distributed species spreading through geographical barriers and different landscapes (
Honacki et al. 1982
; Novak & Paradiso 1983 ; Musser & Carleton 1993 ; Musser & Carleton 2005 ;
Patton et al. 2000
;
Patton et al. 2008
; Weksler & Bonvicino 2015a ).

The phylogenetic relationships within
N. spinosus
have been poorly explored. The phylogenetic reconstruction of sequences of the mitochondrial cytochrome b gene suggests that this species is monophyletic (
Patton et al. 2000
; Catzeflis & Tilak 2009 ; da Silva et al. 2015). However, this phylogenetic hypothesis was made following incomplete geographical sampling; samples were mainly taken from lowland localities from Ecuador , Peru , and eastern Brazilian Amazonia, lacking samples from the type locality of
N. spinosus
sensu stricto from highlands of the Central Andes or from the southern lowlands of the Cerrado. Thus, the true phylogenetic relationships of
N. spinosus
and its subspecies remain unresolved until samples from the entire geographic range are included.

Given the evidence of morphological variation among populations and subspecies, we aim to review
Neacomys spinosus
sensu lato in a morphological and molecular context with emphasis on populations from Peru . We aim the diagnosis of
N. spinosus
sensu stricto to propose taxonomic changes and to describe a new species.

Morphological Samples. We examined a total of 241 adult specimens of
Neacomys spinosus
from 85 localities, which partially cover the distribution of
N. spinosus
. Additionally, we also included specimens of
N. minutus
and
N. musseri
, which are co-distributed with
N. spinosus
, (Appendix I). Specimens used in this study belong in the following museum collections: American Museum of Natural History,
New York
, USA ( AMNH ), Natural History Museum, London, United Kingdom ( BMNH ), Field Museum of Natural History, Chicago, USA ( FMNH ), Museo de Historia Natural de la Universidad Nacional de San Marcos. Lima , Peru ( MUSM ), Museum of Vertebrate Zoology, University of California- Berkeley, California , USA ( MVZ ). National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian Institution, Washington D.C. , USA ( USNM ).

Populations. Operational population units were constrained within the following rivers: Amazonas , Marañon , Ucayali , Huallaga, Apurimac , Urubamba and Inambari. Also, they were constrained along the elevation gradient in the oriental slope of the Andes as lowlands (below ~ 700 m ), premontane forests (~700 to ~ 1200 m ), and montane forests (above ~ 1200 m ) (following Young & León 1999 ).

Qualitative analysis. We used a set of 136 morphological characters scored for each individual. When making comparisons, we considered only those characters that were present in all members of the population and dismissed those with variation among individuals, in order to describe discrete and diagnostic characters (following Wiens 2000 criteria). First, we compared specimens of
N. minutus
and
N. musseri
with populations of
N. spinosus
. Then, we compared the diagnostic characters of each population within
N. spinosus
with photos of
N. spinosus
lectotype ( BMNH 81.9.7.25),
N. spinosus amoenus
type ( BMNH 3.7.7.84), and
N. spinosus carceleni
( UMMZ 80171), and original descriptions. Age classification was made according to the criteria described by Voss (1991) . For the description of the skin and skull-dental characters, we followed Hershkovitz (1962) , Voss (1988) , Carleton & Musser (1989) ,
Patton et al. (2000)
,
Voss et al. (2001)
, Pacheco (2003) , Weksler (2006) ,
Jiménez et al. (2013)
and Rengifo & Pacheco (2015) .

Quantitative analysis. We took two sets of measurements, external and craniodental. Five external measurements were taken from specimens’ labels as follows: Total length (TL): from the tip of the nose to the tip of the terminal tail vertebra; Tail length (T): from the base of the tail to tip of the last vertebra; Hind foot length (F): from the proximal margin of the calcaneus to the tip of longest claw; Ear height (E): from the notch to top of the pinna; and Weight (W). Eighteen craniodental measurements were taken (precision ± 0.01 mm ) of 62 adult specimens, following
Patton et al. (2000)
and
Voss et al. (2001)
: Greatest length of skull (GLS): greatest midline length obtainable from the anterior border of nasal bones to the posterior-most extension of the skull. Condyloincisive Length (CIL): from the greater curvature of one upper incisor to the articular surface of the occipital condyle on the same side. Nasal Length (LN): midline distance from the anterior tip to the posterior border of the nasal bones. Rostral Length (LR): length from the anterior border of the orbit to the midline tip of the nasal bones. Rostral Breadth (BR): breadth of rostrum across nasolacrimal capsule. Zygomatic Breadth (ZB): greatest breadth across zygomatic arches. Breadth of Braincase (BB): greatest transverse dimension across the braincase above and slightly behind the squamosal zygomatic processes. Length of Orbital Foramen (LOF): greatest transverse length from the zygomatic to the squamosal root. Least Interorbital Breadth ( LIB ): shortest distance across the frontal bones between the orbital fossae. Length of Diastema (LD): from the crown of the first cheek tooth to the lesser curvature of the incisor on the same side. Length of Molars (LM): Crown length from M1 to M3. Breadth of Bony palate (BBP): breadth across lateral borders of M1. Length of Bony Palate (LBP): distance from the posterior border of incisive foramen to the posterior border of the palate. Length of Incisive Foramen (LIF): greatest anterior-posterior dimension of one incisive foramen. Breadth of Incisive Foramina (BIF): greatest transverse dimension across both incisive foramina. Breadth of M1 (BM1): greatest crown breadth of the first maxillary molar. Breadth of Zygomatic Plate (BZP): Least distance between the anterior and posterior borders of the zygomatic plate. Length of Zygomatic Arch (LZA): distance length from the anterior border of the zygomatic root to the posterior border of squamosal root.

For statistical analyses, the normality of the data was assessed using a Kolmogorov-Smirnov test. Given that some measurements differed by orders of magnitude, the data were log transformed. In total, 18 variables from 62 individuals were analyzed using a Principal Component Analysis (PCA), based on the variance-covariance matrix. The first PC was used to make an ANOVA using Peruvian populations as fixed factors. The Statistical post hoc analysis Tukey-Kramer test for unbalanced groups was performed (α = 0.05). All statistical analyses were performed using R (R Core Team 2015 ), and Tukey-Kramer test was performed using “DTK” package ( Lau 2013 ).

Molecular methods. Complementarily, the DNA of representatives of Peruvian Populations of
N. spinosus
( MUSM 35076, MUSM 35080, MUSM 35083, MUSM 36924, see Appendix I and II) was extracted, and the cytochrome b gene (801 bp) was amplified and sequenced. Methods for DNA extraction and for the amplifications are detailed in Smith & Patton (1991 , 1999 ); the High Pure PCR Template Preparation Kit (by ®Roche) and the MVZ 0 5 and MVZ 16 primers were used ( Smith & Patton 1993 ). Amplifications were performed in 50 µL reactions with Platinum® Taq Polymerase (InvitrogenẈ) and recommended concentrations of primers and templates. Reactions were run for 35 cycles at 94°C for 45 s, 45°C for 30 s, and extension at 72°C for 90 s, with initial denaturation at 94°C for 3 min and final extension at 72°C for 10 min. Amplified products were sequenced using an external sequencing service (Macrogen, Inc. Korea ); the sequences were edited with CodonCode (http:// www.codoncode.com/aligner/). New sequences were deposited in GenBank with accession numbers KX258225 – KX258228 . In the phylogenetic analyses, we also included 86 sequences of other
Neacomys
species, 62 provided by James L. Patton (deposited with accession numbers KX792021 – KX792082 ) and others retrieved from GenBank. Additionally, sequences of
Handleyomys alfaroi , Oligoryzomys flavescens
,
Oryzomys palustris, Oreozyzomys balneator , Microryzomys minutus
,
Scolomys melanops , Scolomys ucayalensis
, and
Thomasomys baeops
were retrieved from GenBank and used as outgroup. The full list of accession numbers can be found in Appendix II.

Morphological qualitative evidence. Specimens previously recognized as
Neacomys spinosus
(i.e.,
N. spinosus
s.l. ) present large variation in a suite of morphological characters, which seems to be structured into four main groups, the distribution of which are restricted by rivers as well as within elevation gradients: (I) specimens from the Marañon and Huallaga rivers’ basins ranging from
1700 to 2100 m
in altitude (including
Neacomys spinosus spinosus
type series); (II) specimens from the Cerrado (altitudes below 500 m ) of western Bolivia and Central- Western Brazil (including
Neacomys spinosus amoenus
type series); (III) specimens from the Amazon rain forest (below 400m ) from northwestern Ecuador and northwestern Peru (including
Neacomys spinosus carceleni
type series); and (IV) specimens from the Peruvian-Bolivian Yungas ( 700 to 1900m ) from northern Inambari River to center of Bolivia (
Neacomys
sp. nov. ). Differences between these forms are listed in Table 1 , and explained below. Morphological comparisons allow to distinct
N. spinosus
s.l. from
N. minutus
and
N. musseri
. Externally,
N. spinosus
is medium or large body size (HBL 71–106 mm ), and
N. musseri
and
N. minutus
are always small body size (HBL 65-79 mm , and 73–76 mm , respectively); tails are longer or smaller than the head-body length in
N. spinosus
(> ~20%), and equal size or slightly longer in
N. minutus
and
N. musseri
(~0%–~5%); ventral fur is grayish white or white in
N. spinosus
, while it is completely white in
N. minutus
and
N. musseri
; hind feet are large or small in
N. spinosus
, and always small in
N. minutus
and
N. musseri
. Cranially, skulls are medium to large size in
N. spinosus
(CIL 18.82–20.50 mm ), and small in
N. minutus
and
N. musseri
(CIL 16.84–18.74 mm , and 18.52– 19.48 mm , respectively).

subSection.paragraph:
Cranial characters also provide evidence for the distinction of these taxa. For instance, skulls of
N. s. spinosus
and
Neacomys
sp. nov. are small size, and
N. s. amoenus
and
N. s. carceleni
are large sized ( Table 2 , Fig. 1 ); the most anterior part of the suture between nasal and premaxillary bones does not reach the zygomatic root level in
N. s. spinosus
, but reach in
Neacomys
sp. nov. ,
N. s. amoenus
and
N. s. carceleni
; gnathic process is large in
N. s. carceleni
, but short in
N. s. spinosus
,
Neacomys
sp. nov. and
N. s. amoenus
; zygomatic notch is deep in
N. s. amoenus
, but shallow in
N. s. spinosus
,
Neacomys
sp. nov. and
N. s. carceleni
; lacrimals are rounded with twothirds dip in frontal bone in
N. s. spinosus
and
N. s. amoenus
, square with one-half dip in frontal bone in
N. s. carceleni
, and rounded with one-half dip in frontal bone in
Neacomys
sp. nov. ; interorbital beads are moderately developed in
N. s. spinosus
and
N. s. amoenus
, well developed in
N. s. carceleni
and poorly developed in
Neacomys
sp. nov. ( Fig. 1 ); inner border of incisive foramina are posteriorly parallel in
N. s. spinosus
and
N. s. carceleni
, and convergent in
Neacomys
sp. nov. and
N. s. amoenus
( Fig. 1 ); diastema is flattened in
N. s. spinosus
,
N. s. amoenus
and
Neacomys
sp. nov. , but exhibit a small hump in
N. s. carceleni
; origin of the superficial masseter is circular and flat in
N. s. spinosus
and
N. s. carceleni
, ovoid and flat in
N. s. amoenus
, and ovoid and protruded in
Neacomys
sp. nov. ; maxillary-palatine suture is at the hypocone or hypoflexus level of M 1 in
N. s. spinosus
and
N. s. carceleni
, at the hypocone level of M 1 in
N. s. amoenus
, and at the hypoflexus level of M 1 in
Neacomys
sp. nov. ; posterior palatine foramina is at the protoflexus level of M 2 in
N. s. spinosus
,
N. s. amoenus
and
N. s. carceleni
, but at the hypocone level of M 1 in
Neacomys
sp. nov. ; sphenopalatine vacuities are large in
N. s. spinosus
and
Neacomys
sp. nov. , medium in
N. s. amoenus
, and small and almost closed in
N. s. carceleni
( Fig. 1 ); presphenoid is broad with straight lateral borders in
N. s. spinosus
,
N. s. amoenus
and
N. s. carceleni
, but laterally compressed with concave lateral borders in
Neacomys
sp. nov. ( Fig. 1 ); alisphenoid strut is always present in
N. s. spinosus
, but always absent in
N. s. amoenus
,
N. s. carceleni
and
Neacomys
sp. nov. ( Fig. 2 ); Eustachian tube is short in
N. s. spinosus
and
N. Neacomys
sp. nov. , but large in
N. s. amoenus
and
N. s. carceleni
( Fig. 1 ); bullae capsule is globular in
N. s. spinosus
,
N. s. amoenus
and
N. s. carceleni
, but flask shaped in
Neacomys
sp. nov. ( Fig. 1 ); external border of the pterygoid plates is straight in
N. s. spinosus
,
N. s. amoenus
and
N. s. carceleni
, but convex in
Neacomys
sp. nov. ( Fig. 1 ); anterior bullae process is in contact with the pterygoid plate in
N. s. carceleni
, almost in contact with the pterygoid plate in
N. s. spinosus
, but not in contact in
N. s. amoenus
and
Neacomys
sp. nov. ( Fig. 1 ); basioccipital breadth is subequal to the breadth among M 2 in
N. s. spinosus
,
N. s. carceleni
and
Neacomys
sp. nov. , but narrower in
N. s. amoenus
( Fig. 1 ); basioccipital pits are shallow in
N. s. spinosus
,
N. s. amoenus
and
Neacomys
sp. nov. , but deep in
N. s. carceleni
( Fig. 1 ); anterior border of the foramen magnum exhibit a notch in
N. s. carceleni
and
Neacomys
sp. nov. , but not in
N. s. spinosus
and
N. s. amoenus
; masseteric crest of the jaw is below the procingulum of the m 1 in
N. s. spinosus
,
N. s. amoenus
and
Neacomys
sp. nov. , and below of the hypoconid of the m 1 in
N. s. carceleni
; coronoid process is thick in
N. s. spinosus
,
N. s. amoenus
and
N. s. carceleni
, but slightly thin in
Neacomys
sp. nov. ; condylar process is large and thin in
N. s. spinosus
and
Neacomys
sp. nov. , but short and broad in
N. s. amoenus
and
N. s. carceleni
; crest between condylar and angular processes is shallow in
N. s. spinosus
,
N. s. amoenus
and
Neacomys
sp. nov. , but deep in
N. s. carceleni
.

subSection.paragraph:

(A, E: MUSM 7926),

subSection.paragraph:
Morphological quantitative evidence. Eigenvalues and percentages of variation of the first five principal components (PC) are presented in Table 3 . PC1 represents 75.8% of the total variation explained by the variable GLS and BBP, PC2 represents 9.7% of the total variation explained by the variable GLS and LM, and PC3 represents 4.0 % of the total variation explained by the variable LR and LIB . The plot of eigenvalues of PC 2 in response of eigenvalues of PC1 represents 85.5% of total variation (Fig. 4A). Graphically the PCA shows that
N. s. spinosus
,
N. s. carceleni
,
N. s. amoenus
, and
Neacomys
sp. nov. occupy different morphospaces. The ANOVA using PC1 as response variable and taxa as factors shows significant differences between groups p <0.001 F = 77.37 (Fig. 4B) and post hoc Tukey-Kramer test (
N. s. spinosus – N. s. carceleni
p<0.01,
N. s. spinosus – N. s. amoenus
p<0.01,
N. s. spinosus – Neacomys
sp. nov. p<0.01,
N. s. carceleni – N. s. amoenus
p<0.01,
N. s. carceleni – Neacomys
sp. nov. p<0.01,
N. s. spinosus – Neacomys
sp. nov. p<0.01,) corroborates that groups are distinct each other; which support statistically that each group occupies different morphospaces.

Molecular evidence. Similar topologies were recovered using both Maximum Likelihood and Bayesian Inference ( Fig. 5 ). Regarding phylogenetic relationships,
Neacomys
is recovered as monophyletic group (BS = 71%, PP = 0.99) formed by three clades. We propose that these clades represent groups of species: the “
paracou
” group (BS = 99%, PP = 1.00) which is the sister group of “
spinosus
” group (BS = 99%, PP = 1.00), and “
tenuipes
” group (BS = 70%, PP = 0.93). The “
paracou
” group is monotypic, formed by
N. paracou
. The “
spinosus
” group is formed by
N. spinosus
,
N. amoenus s.l
(BS = 100%, PP = 1.00), and
Neacomys
sp. nov. (BS = 93%, PP = 1.00). The “
tenuipes
” group is formed by
N. tenuipes
,
N. guianae
(BS = 100%, PP = 1.00),
Neacomys
sp. “clade 3” (BS = 99%, PP = 1.00),
N. minutus
s.l. (BS = 99%, PP = 1.00),
N. musseri
(BS = 100%, PP = 1.00),
N. dubosti
(BS = 100%, PP = 1.00),
Neacomys
sp. “clade 6” (following
Patton et al. 2000
, BS = 93%, PP = 1.00), and
Neacomys
sp. “clade 7” (following
Patton et al. 2000
).

Within the “
spinosus
” group,
Neacomys
sp. nov. is the sister group of the remaining species (BS = 99%, PP = 1.00). These latter species are grouped into one clade (BS = 71%, PP = 0.93) formed by
N. spinosus
+
N. amoenus
s.l. (BS = 99%, PP = 1.00). On the other hand, the “
tenuipes
” group is a polytomy formed by
N. tenuipes
, clade formed by
N. minutus
s.l. +
N. musseri
+
Neacomys
sp. “clade 3” (BS = 43%, PP = 0.83), the clade formed by
Neacomys
sp. “clade 7” +
N. dubosti
(BS = 71%, PP = 0.98), and the clade formed by
N. guianae
+
Neacomys
sp. “clade 6” (BS = 91%, PP = 0.97).

caption.paragraph: TABLE 3. Factor loadings for the first five components of the PCA of skull variables. Bold numbers indicate the eigenvector of the variable that explains most of the variance for each component.

subSection.paragraph:
The observed interspecific variation of
Neacomys
was 11.4% ± 0.7.
Neacomys
sp. nov. presents an intraspecific variation of 1.8% ± 0.3, and differs from
N. spinosus
by 7.8% ± 1.0, and from
N. amoenus
s.l. by 8.8 % ± 0.9.
N. s. spinosus
differs from
N. amoenus
by 8.1% ± 1.0, which presents an intraspecific variation of 2.0% ± 0.3.

Additionally, phylogenetic relationships show that
N. amoenus
s.l. is formed by four well-supported clades:
N. a. amoenus
s.s. (BS = 99%, PP = 1.00, corroborated by morphological evidence),
N. a. carceleni
s.s. (BS = 62%, PP = 0.94, corroborates by morphological evidence),
N. amoenus
“Central Andes-Amazonia” - CAA (BS = 80%, PP = 0.96), and the single haplotype
N. amoenus
“Northern Peru ” ( KX792082 ). The genetic distances between these groups show that
N. a. amoenus
s.s. presents an intraspecific variation of 1.2% ± 0.2, and differs from
N. a. carceleni
s.s. by 3.5% ± 0.5, from clade
N. amoenus “
CAA” by 2.2% ± 0.5, and from
N. amoenus
“Northern Peru ” by 2.4% ± 0.5;
N. a. carceleni
s.s presents an intraspecific variation of 1.2% ± 1.3, and differs from
N. amoenus
“CAA” by 3.0% ± 0.6, and from
N. amoenus
“Northern Peru ” by 2.3% ± 0.5; and
N. amoenus
“CAA” presents a an intraspecific variation of 0.6% ± 0.1, and differs from haplotype
N. amoenus
“Northern Peru ” by 1.6% ± 0.4. Given the distances among these four clades are smaller than the interspecific variation among
Neacomys
, consequently, we considered provisionally the set of these clades as
N. amoenus
s.l. according to the Principle of Priority of the ICZN (1999, Article 23).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3. Top: comparisons of the upper molar row. Bottom: comparisons of the lower molar row. M1 : first upper molar. M2 : second upper molar. M3 : third upper molar. m1 : first lower molar. m2 : second lower molar. m3 : third lower molar. af: anteromedian flexus, atl : anteroloph, msl : mesoloph, plfd : posterolophid, ptf : protoflexus, ptl : posteroloph.
Neacomys s. spinosus
(A, E: MUSM 7926),
N. s. amoenus
(B, F: AMNH 37099),
N. s. carceleni
(C, G: MUSM 30367), and
Neacomys
sp. nov. (D, H MUSM 35069).

subSection.paragraph:
Given the evidence from the morphological and molecular analyses, we conclude that
N. spinosus
s.l. is a monophyletic group and a complex of species. From this, we recognize that
N. spinosus
s.s. is a full species; while
N. amoenus
s.l. is a complex of taxa, where
N. amoenus amoenus
and
N. amoenus carceleni
are maintained as subspecies, and also we distinguish and describe
Neacomys
sp. nov.

subSubSection.paragraph: Large Spiny Mouse

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Neacomys spinosus spinosus :
Gyldenstolpe, 1932 :34
N [ eacomys ]. s [ pinosus ]. typicus
Thomas, 1900 :153
Oryzomys spinosus
: E.-
L. Trouessart, 1897 :528

subSubSection.paragraph: Lectotype. BMNH 81.9.7.25, adult male, skin, and skull, collected in 1801 by M. Stolzmann without collector number.

Type locality
. “…Huambo.- a plantation in the forest of the same name, to the east of Chachapoyas and Chirimoto, 3700 feet in altitude, on the banks of the river Huambo, a tributary of the Huallaga…”, Thomas, 1882 :99, approximately 1127 m , 6°34’S , 77°22.5’W , Huambo, Chachapoyas, Amazonas , Peru ( Fig. 6 )

Emended diagnosis.
Neacomys spinosus
is distinguished from other congeners by the combination of the following characters: reddish dorsal fur, long genal vibrissae, pale white ventral fur with gray bases, short carpal vibrissae, carpal and metatarsal patches always present, large forefeet, long tail, tapering rostrum, supraorbital beads moderately developed, inner border of the incisive foramina is posteriorly parallel, alisphenoid strut always present, large and slim condylar process, procingulum of M1 anteriorly flattened, short posteroloph, and deep protoflexus in M1.

Distribution.
Neacomys spinosus
is distributed in the Peruvian mountain cloud forests of Amazonas , San Martín , and Huánuco , from Southern Rio Marañon to Northern Rio Huallaga; elevation range is from
1127 to 2100 m
.

Morphological description. Medium size. Dorsal fur is reddish brown; soft hairs are dark brown with reddish-orange tips and spines are white with black tips; dorsal hair length is 9 mm in average at the rump level; flanks are reddish. Ventral fur is white with gray on the basal half; ventral fur length is 4 mm in average at belly level. Hairs of ungual manus tufts pass claws slightly. Fifth forefeet digit passes the second interphalangeal joint of the fourth digit. Metacarpal patch is large, between second and fourth digit, with dark scales and hairs. Carpal vibrissae are short reaching the base of the fifth digit. Genal vibrissae pass the posterior border of the pinna. Superciliary vibrissae do not pass the posterior border of the pinna. Interramal vibrissae are inserted in a basal protuberance. Hind feet are thick and large, almost twice forefeet length. Ungual pedal tufts do not pass claws. First pedal digit reaches second digit base; the fifth digit reaches the second interphalangeal joint of the fourth digit. Metatarsal patch is present. Plantar squamation is restricted to pad region. Tail is approximately 20 % longer than head-body length. Upper hairs of the tail are black, covering 1.5–2 scales; lower hairs are whitish, covering 2 scales. Terminal pencil presents scarce long hairs.

Skull . ( Fig. 7 ) Dorsal view. Rostrum is broad and tapering. Anterior borders of the nasals are rounded. Posterior borders of the nasals are irregularly rounded, behind premaxillary-maxillary-frontal joint and maxillaryfrontal-lacrimal joints. Sutures between premaxillary and frontal bones are short and separate. Zygomatic notch is shallow; not enclosing the lacrimal foramen. Lacrimals are rounded; two-third dips in frontal bone, one-third dips in zygomatic bone. Interorbital beads are moderately developed.

Lateral view. Skull profile is flattened. Rostrum is anteriorly flat. Gnathic process is small. The most anterior part of the suture between nasal and premaxillary bones does not reach the squamosal zygomatic root. Breadth of the maxillary root of zygomatic is one-third upper row molar length. Breadth of the zygomatic plate and the squamosal root of zygomatic are subequal. Ethmoid and sphenopalatine foramina are placed at the anterior border of the M2. Ethmoturbinals are square shaped and its diameter is about one-half of M3. Alisphenoid strut is always present. Tegmen tympani do not overlap the posterior process of the squamosal. Orbicular apophysis of the malleus bone is large and globose; manubrium is large, and the lamina is rectangle and deep. Processus brevis of the incus is smaller than the incus breadth. Postglenoid foramina are continuous with the middle lacerate foramina. Mastoid tubercle is interiorly concave. Dorsal margins of postglenoid foramina and subsquamosal fenestra are rounded and reach the upper border of the mastoid. Hamular process is thick. Mastoid perforation is always present, with variable position, size, and shape.

Ventral view. Inner borders of the incisive foramina are posteriorly parallel. Incisive foramina breadth is about the length of M2-M3. Septum is narrow. Diastema is flat. Origin of the superficial masseter is circular and flat, placed at the anterior border of the zygomatic plate. Maxillary-palatine suture is placed among hypocone and hypoflexus of M1. Posterior palatine foramina are at the protoflexus level of M2. Posterolateral palatal pits are large and ovoid shaped, ranging from hypocone of M3 to the anterior mesopterygoid border. Sphenopalatine vacuities are large, occupying the basisphenoid and presphenoid area, with irregular borders. Presphenoid is triangle shaped, and broad with straight borders. Mesopterygoid fossa breadth is subequal to incisive foramina breadth. Parapterygoid processes are parallel; laterally, they reach to molar surface level. External borders of the pterygoid plate are straight. Fontanellae breadth is as M3 length. Posterior opening of the alisphenoid canal is broad, as M2 breadth. Groove of the infraorbital branch of the stapedial artery is deep. Middle lacerate foramina breadth is half of M2 length. Eustachian tube is short and wide. Bullas are globular. Anterior process of bullae is in contact with the pterygoid plate. Basioccipital breadth is subequal to breadth between second upper molars, at petrosal level. Basioccipital pits are shallow. Anterior border of the foramen magnum is obtuse V-shaped.

Jaw. Masseteric crest is below the procingulum the m1. Mental foramen is at the labial border of the diastema. Capsular process is moderately developed, but does not pass the condylar process. Coronoid process is short and thick. Condylar process is large and thin. Angular process is short. Crest between the condylar and angular process is shallow. Ventral border of the jaw is slightly concave.

Teeth. Upper. Incisors are opisthodont, with rounded tips and yellow-orange enamel bands. Molar rows are parallel. Procingulum of M1 is anteriorly rounded, narrow and symmetrically divided. Anteroflexus of M1 reaches labial surface. Mesoloph of M1 is perpendicular to the labial surface. Posteroloph of M1 reaches the labial surface. Anteroloph of M2 is thin and reaches the labial surface. Protoflexus of M2 is shallow. Mesoloph of M2 is perpendicular to the labial surface. Posteroloph of M2 reaches the molar surface. Posterior border posteroloph of M2 is rounded. Anteroloph of M3 reaches the paracone surface. Lower. Procingulum of m1 is symmetrically divided. Mesolophid of m1 is narrow. Hypoflexid of m1 is perpendicular to the labial surface. Posterior border of posterolophid of m1 is convex, does not reach the lingual surface. Anterolabial cingulum of m2 is broad. Posterior border of posterolophid of m2 is convex and reaches the lingual surface.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Natural history.
Neacomys spinosus
is an endemic species from Peru , with restricted distribution to Mountain cloud forests between Marañón and Huallaga Rivers. Not much is known about this species.
Leo & Romo (1992)
recorded some individuals in the headwaters of the Río Abiseo , within the
Parque Nacional Río Abiseo
, and reported the highest altitudinal range of this species (
2375 m
). They also mentioned that specimens were collected on the ground, in riverine vegetation in a sandy beach, with traps placed above cane and shrubs a few centimeters above the ground.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. Thomas (1900) used N. s. typicus to name individuals from the type series of
N. spinosus
, which were compared with
N. s. tenuipes
. For this reason, typicus is still considered a junior synonym of
N. spinosus
.

bibRefCitation.author: Thomas
bibRefCitation.refString: Thomas, O. (1903) On the mammals collected by Mr. A. Robert at Chapada, Matto Grosso (Percy Sladen Expedition to Central Brazil). Proceedings Zoological Society of London, 1903, 232 - 244.

subSubSection.paragraph: Pleasant Spiny Mouse
Holotype. Adult male, skin, and skull BMNH 3.7.7.84, collected 11th August 1902 by A. Robert, original number 1077.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Type locality.
“…village situated at an altitude of about
800 m
.
, on the Serra do Chapada , some thirty miles N.E. of Cubayá …”,
Thomas , 1903
:233, between 700 to 900 meters, approximately 15°30’S , 55°31’W , Serra do Chapada , Chapada do Guimarães , Cuiabá , Mato Grosso , Brazil ( Fig. 6 ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Emended diagnosis.
Neacomys amoenus amoenus
is distinguishable from other species for the combination of following characters: pale orange dorsal fur, pale yellowish flanks, ungual manus tufts do not pass the claws, metacarpal and metatarsal patches always absent, short carpal and genal vibrissae, slim and long forefeet, deep zygomatic notch, interorbital beads are moderately developed, inner border of the incisive foramina are posteriorly convergent, the origin of the superficial masseter ovoid and flat, medium size sphenopalatine vacuities, narrow basioccipital, short and broad condylar process, large posteroloph of M1, and shallow protoflexus of M2.

Distribution .
Neacomys amoenus amoenus
inhabit in the Cerrado, in the Northern Mato Grosso in Brazil , and Northeastern Santa Cruz in Bolivia from
200 to 900 m
.

Morphological description. Large size. Dorsal fur is pale Orange Brown; soft hairs are light brown with pale orange tips; spines are white with gray tips; fur length is 9 mm in average at the rump level; flanks are pale yellowish orange. Ventral fur is smoky white with the short gray base; its length is 4 mm in average at belly level. Ungual manus tufts do not pass the claws. Fifth digit of forefeet passes the first interphalangeal joint of the fourth digit. Metacarpal patch is absent. Carpal vibrissae reach the base of the fifth digit. Genal and superciliary vibrissae do not pass the posterior border of the pinna. Interramal vibrissae are inserted in a basal protuberance. Hind feet are slim and large, almost twice forefeet length. Ungual pedal tufts do not pass claws. First pedal digit reaches the first interphalangeal joint of second digit; fifth digit reaches the second interphalangeal joint of the fourth. Metatarsal patch is absent. Plantar squamation is on the pad and hypothenar region. Tail is around 5% longer than head-body length. Upper hairs of the tail are black, covering 1–2 scale; lower hairs are white and cover 1–2.5 scales. Tail scale length average is 1.1 mm . Terminal pencil of hairs presents scarce long hairs.

Skull. ( Fig. 8 ) Dorsal view. Rostrum is broad and truncated. Anterior borders of nasals are rounded. Posterior borders of nasals are irregular, is behind premaxillary-maxillary-frontal joint and maxillary-frontal-lacrimal joints. Dorsal sutures between maxillary-frontal are short. Zygomatic notch is deep, not enclosing lacrimal foramen. Lacrimals are rounded; one-half is inserted on the squamosal root of zygomatic. Lateral process of frontals is slightly developed. Interorbital beads are moderately developed.

Lateral view. Skull profile is flattened. Rostrum is anteriorly flat. Gnathic process protrudes slightly over incisor surface. The most anterior part of the suture between nasal and premaxillary bones reaches squamosal zygomatic root. Breadth of the maxillary root of zygomatic is as the M3 length. Breadth of the zygomatic plate is as M1 and one-half M2 length. Breadth of the squamosal root of zygomatic is smaller than the breadth of the zygomatic plate. Ethmoid foramen is at the middle point of M2 level. Sphenopalatine foramen is placed at the anterior border of M2. Ethmoturbinals diameter is as one-half of M3 length. Alisphenoid strut is always absent. Tegmen tympani do not overlap the posterior process of the squamosal. Mastoid tubercle is anteriorly concave. Apophysis orbicular of malleus bone is globose and short; the lamina is shallow. Processus brevis of the incus is large, subequal to the incus breadth. Dorsal margin of postglenoid foramina and subsquamosal fenestra are rounded. Hamular process is thick. Mastoid perforation is as M2 length and placed posteriorly.

Ventral view. Inner borders of the incisive foramina are posteriorly convergent. Incisive foramina breadth is about M2-M3 length. Septum is narrow. Diastema is flat. Origin of the superficial masseter is ovoid and flat, placed behind of the anterior zygomatic-plate border. Maxillary-palatine suture is at hypocone of M1 level. Posterior palatine foramina are at the protoflexus level of M2. Posterolateral palatal pits are small, placed at the anterior mesopterygoid border. Sphenopalatine vacuities are medium size, occupying the basisphenoid and presphenoid. Presphenoid is broad and triangular with straight lateral borders. Mesopterygoid fossa breadth is subequal to incisive foramina breadth. Parapterygoid processes are parallel; laterally, they reach to molar surface level. External borders of the pterygoid plate are straight. Fontanellae breadth is one-half of M3 length. Posterior opening of the alisphenoid canal is broad, as M2 length. Groove of the infraorbital branch of stapedial artery is wide and deep. Middle lacerate foramina breadth is as M2 length. Eustachian tube is large and wide. Bullas are globular shaped. Anterior process of bullae is not in contact with the pterygoid plate. Basioccipital breadth at petrosal level is lesser than breadth between second upper molars. Basioccipital pits are shallow. Anterior border of the foramen magnum is obtuse V-shaped.

Jaw. Masseteric crest is below the procingulum of the m1. Mental foramen is at the labial border of the diastema. Capsular process is moderately developed, but does not pass the condylar process. Coronoid process is thick. Condylar process is short and broad. Angular process is short. Crest between condylar and angular process is shallow and rounded. Ventral border of the jaw is slightly concave.

Teeth. Upper. Incisors are opisthodont, with rounded tips and yellow-orange enamel bands. Molar rows are parallel. Procingulum of M1 is anteriorly rounded. Procingulum of M1 is broad and symmetrically divided. Anteroflexus of M1 reaches the labial surface. Mesoloph of M1 is perpendicular to the labial surface. Posteroloph of M1 reaches the labial surface; its posterior border is convex. Anteroloph of M2 is broad and reaches the labial surface. Protoflexus of M2 is shallow. Mesoloph of M2 is antero-posteriorly convex. Posteroloph of M2 reaches the molar surface. Posterior border of posteroloph of M2 is rounded. Anteroloph of M3 reaches the paracone surface. Lower. Procingulum of m1 is symmetrically divided. Mesolophid of m1 is broad. Hypoflexid of m1 is perpendicular to the labial surface. Posterior border of posterolophid of m1 is straight and reaches the lingual surface. Anterolabial cingulum of m2 is narrow. Posterior border of posterolophid of m2 is convex and reaches the lingual surface.

Natural history. Not much of
Neacomys amoenus amoenus
is known, it inhabits in the Cerrado ecosystems within Brazil and Bolivia;
which unfortunately are being deforested by anthropic activities. Nevertheless, given the distribution of
N. a. amoenus
, two areas of preservation could keep this species: Parque Nacional da Chapada dos Guimarães in Brazil (www.mma.gov.br/areas-protegidas) and Parque Nacional Noel Kempff Mercado in Bolivia (www.sernap.gob.bo).

Remarks.
Patton et al. (2000)
suggested keeping
“ amoenus
” as a junior synonym of
N. spinosus
, based on comparisons between the type series of “
amoenus ”
with individuals of
N. spinosus
from Juruá River. However, those specimens named
spinosus
are here referred as clade
N. amoenus
“Central Andes-Amazonia” (see below, also Appendix II).

bibRefCitation.author: Hershkovitz
bibRefCitation.refString: Hershkovitz, P. (1940) A new spiny mouse of the genus Neacomys from Eastern Ecuador. Occasional Papers of the Museum of Zoology of University of Michigan, 419, 1 - 4.

subSubSection.paragraph: Alberto Carcelén’s Spiny Mouse
Holotype. Adult male, skin, and skull U.M.M.Z. 80171, collected 5th October 1936 by Philip Hershkovitz, original number M618.

Type locality.
“ Llunchi , an island on the northern side of the Rio Napo , west of the mouth of the Rio Jivino , latitude and longitude approximately 0°37’ S .
,
76° 46’ W .; parish of La Coca , Napo-Pastaza Province , Ecuador ; altitude about 250 meters.”
Hershkovitz , 1940
:1 ( Fig. 6 ).

Emended diagnosis.
Neacomys amoenus carceleni
is different from other
Neacomys
because presents large body size, ventral fur completely white and short, long ungual manus tufts and carpal vibrissae, short hind feet, metatarsal and metacarpal patches always absent, tail subequal to head-body pencil of hairs is absent, rostrum broad and tapering with lateral humps, large gnathic process, squared lacrimals, well-developed interorbital beads, upper molar rows posteriorly convergent, diastema with a hump, anterior bullae process in contact with pterygoid plate, deep basioccipital pits, masseteric crest of the jaw below the hypoconid of the m1, deep crest between condylar and angular processes, anteroloph of M1 broad and asymmetrically divided, posteroloph of M1 large with a straight posterior border, and shallow protoflexus of M2.

Distribution. Distribution of
Neacomys amoenus carceleni
occurs in the Amazon basin, in Pastaza and Francisco de Orellana Provinces of Ecuador ; Loreto , Madre de Dios and Ucayali Departments of Peru ; and the Acre and Amazonas States of Brazil . Ranged from
200 to 750 m
.

Morphological description. Large size. Dorsal fur is pale orange-brown; soft hairs are dark brown with pale orange tips, spines are white with gray tips; its length is 11 mm in average at the rump level; flanks are pale ochraceous. Ventral fur is completely white; it is short in length, 3 mm in average at the belly. Ungual manus tufts pass the claws. Fifth forefeet digit reaches the claw base of the fourth digit. Metacarpal patch is small, with colored hairs. Carpal vibrissae pass the second interphalangeal joint of the fifth digit. Genal and superciliary vibrissae pass the posterior pinna border. Basal protuberances for interramal vibrissae insertion are absent. Hind feet are slim and short, one-third larger than forefeet. Ungual pedal tufts do not pass the claws. First pedal digit passes the first interphalangeal joint of the second; fifth digit reaches the second interphalangeal joint of the fourth. Metatarsal patch is absent. Plantar squamation is on the pad and hypothenar region. Tail is subequal to head-body length. Upper tail hairs are black and cover 1–2.5 scales; lower hairs are whitish brown and cover 2–3.5 scales. Terminal pencil of hairs is absent.

Skull. ( Fig. 9 ) Dorsal view. Rostrum is broad and tapering, with lateral humps at premaxillary-maxillary suture level. Anterior borders of the nasals are rounded; sometimes exhibit a cleft between bones. Posterior borders of the nasals are irregularly rounded, behind premaxillary-maxillary-frontal joint and maxillary-frontal-lacrimal joints. Sutures between premaxillary-frontal are large and numerous. Zygomatic notch is shallow; does not enclose lacrimal foramen. Lacrimals are squared; one-half dip on squamosal root of zygomatic bone, and one-half in the frontal bone. Interorbital beads are well developed, but they are less developed in young individuals.

Lateral view. Skull profile is flat, but it exhibits a hump at frontal level. The most anterior part of the suture between nasal and premaxillary bones reaches the squamosal zygomatic root. Gnathic process is large, as the width of one upper incisive. Maxillary root width of zygomatic is as the M2 length. Zygomatic plate breadth is subequal to upper molar row length. Squamosal root breadth of zygomatic is one-half of zygomatic plate breadth. Ethmoid foramen is placed at the metacone of M1. Sphenopalatine foramen is placed at paracone of M2 level. Ethmoturbinals are rounded; they are as one-half of M3 length. Alisphenoid strut is always absent. Tegmen tympani are in contact with the posterior process of the squamosal. Malleus bone exhibits a large manubrium and a globose and large orbicular apophysis; the lamina of the malleus is rectangle and shallow. Processus brevis of incus is large, subequal to incus breadth, and well developed. Mastoid tubercle is not anteriorly concave. Upper border of postglenoid foramen is rounded. Subsquamosal upper border is tapered. Hamular process is thick. Mastoid perforation is present or absent, when is present it is posteriorly placed, with variable size and shape.

Ventral view. Inner borders of the incisive foramina are posteriorly parallel. Incisive foramina breadth is about M1-M2 length. Septum of incisive foramina is narrow. Diastema is not flat; presents a small hump. Origin of the superficial masseter is circular and flat. Maxillary-palatine suture is between hypocone and hypoflexus of M1 level. Posterior palatine foramina are at the protoflexus level of M2. Posterolateral palatal pits are placed from hypocone of M3 to anterior border of mesopterygoid fossa. Sphenopalatine vacuities are small or medium extended. Presphenoid is broad and with straight lateral borders. Mesopterygoid fossa breadth is lesser than incisive foramina breadth. Parapterygoid processes are convergent; laterally, they pass the molar surface level. Lateral borders of pterygoid plate are convex. Fontanellae are absent. Posterior opening of the alisphenoid canal is as M3 length. Groove for the infraorbital branch of the stapedial artery is shallow and wide. Middle lacerate foramina are narrow, as one-half of M2 length. Eustachian tube is large and thick. Bullas are globular. Anterior process of the bullae is in contact with the pterygoid plate. Basioccipital at petrosal level is broader than incisive foramina breadth. Basioccipital pits are deep. Anterior border of the foramen magnum is V obtuse shaped.

Jaw. Masseteric crest is below the hypoconid of the m1. Mental foramen is at the labial border of the diastema. Capsular process is moderately developed but does not pass the condylar process. Coronoid process is thick. Condylar process is short and broad. Angular process is short. Crest between condylar and angular processes are deep. Ventral border of the jaw is concave.

Teeth. Upper. Incisors are opisthodont, with rounded tips and golden-orange enamel bands. Molar rows are posteriorly convergent. Procingulum of M1 is anteriorly rounded, broad and asymmetrically divided. Anteroflexus of M1 is enclosed by the anterolabial and the anteroloph. Mesoloph is perpendicular to the labial surface. Posteroloph of M1 reaches the labial surface. Anteroloph of M2 is broad and do not reach the labial surface. Protoflexus of M2 is shallow. Mesoloph of M2 is perpendicular. Posteroloph of M2 does not reach the molar surface. Posterior border of the posteroloph of M2 is rounded. Lower. Procingulum of m1 is symmetrically divided. Mesolophid of m1 is narrow and do not reach the lingual surface. Hypoflexid of m1 is perpendicular to the labial surface. Posterior border of posterolophid of m1 is straight and reaches the lingual surface. Anterolabial cingulum of m2 is broad. Posterior border of posterolophid of m2 is straight and reaches the lingual surface.

Natural history.
Neacomys amoenus carceleni
occurs in the Amazonia from Peru , Ecuador and western Brazil going through Amazon and Marañon Rivers; inhabiting both secondary growth forests and cultivated areas ( Hice & Velazco 2012 ). Regarding reproduction, captured females were pregnant during dry season (between June and September) as in rainy season (between February and March), and lactating between November and December ( Hice & Velazco 2012 ); whereas males were recorded with scrotal testes in June, August, September, November, and December ( Hice & Velazco 2012 ).

Remarks. Hice & Velazco (2012) named individuals of
N. a. carceleni
as
N. spinosus
and provided a short description and figures of the skull, which agree with the diagnosis of
N. a. carceleni
( Hershkovitz 1940; this study ). Furthermore, Hice & Velazco (2012) recorded a candidate species from specimens caught with
N. a. carceleni
into the Reserva Nacional Allpahuayo-Mishana, and suggested that these species have a partition of habitats. The candidate species proposed by Hice & Velazco (2012) might be the specimens labeled as
Neacomys
sp. “clade 3” by
Patton et al. (2000)
, due that two different clades were pointed out as co-distributed by these authors. Given that the names available in the synonymy of the genus are junior synonyms of
N. amoenus
s.l. (e.g.
amoenus , carceleni
) and of
N spinosus
(e.g. typicus ) (this study), the candidate species proposed by Hice & Velazco (2012) is still pending of description.
Mario’s Spiny Mouse

subSubSection.paragraph: Holotype. MUSM 35069, adult male, skin, and skull, collected on 9th May 2010 by Carlos Jiménez, original number 463.

Paratype. Seven adult specimens (MUSM 35063, 35066, 35071, 35073, 35074, 35081, and 35083) preserved as skull and skin. Selected measurements of the holotype and paratype specimens are provided in Table 4 .

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 4. Measurements of the type series of
Neacomys vargasllosai
sp. nov. from Sandia, Puno, Peru. The number in the column heading is the MUSM catalogue number. Age and sex are in parentheses, f = female, m = male.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Type locality.
Yanahuaya , Sandia , Puno , Peru ,
1652 m
. 14°14.5’ S , 69°10’ W ( Fig. 6 ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution.
Neacomys vargasllosai
is distributed from southern Peru , northern the Inambari River watershed in Puno , to southern Bolivia , western Santa Cruz .

Diagnosis.
Neacomys vargasllosai
is medium sized rodent distinguished from other congeners by the combination of the following characters: dark brown dorsal fur, dull white with gray basis ventral fur, small metacarpal patch, tapering rostrum, flask-shaped bullae, convex pterygoid plate, presphenoid with concave lateral borders, antero-posteriorly convex and short mesoloph of M1, short and convex posteroloph of M1, deep protoflexus of M2, antero-posteriorly convex mesoloph of M2, straight and short posterolophid of m1, narrow anterolabial cingulum of m2, and straight posterior border of the posterolophid of m2.

Morphological description. Medium size. Dorsal fur is dark brown; soft hairs are dark brown with pale orange tips; fur length is 10 mm in average at rump level. Flanks are narrow and yellowish orange. Ventral fur is dull white, with gray roots; ventral fur length is 4 mm in average at belly level. Ungual manus tufts pass slightly the claws. Fifth digit of the forefeet passes the second interphalangeal joint of the fourth. Metacarpal patch is small, between II and III finger base, with colored scales and hairs. Carpal vibrissae pass the first interphalangeal joint of the fifth digit. Genal vibrissae do not pass the posterior border of the pinna. Mystacial and superciliary vibrissae pass the posterior border of the pinna. Interramal are inserted on basal protuberances. Hind feet are almost twice forefeet length. Ungual pedal tufts overlap claws. First pedal digit reaches the second digit base, and the fifth digit reaches the second interphalangeal joint of the fourth. Metatarsal patch is absent. Plantar squamation is restricted to the pad region. Tail is around 40 % longer than head-body length. Upper tail hairs are black and they cover 1–2.5 scales; lower hairs are whitish and cover 1.5–3 scales. Pencil present scarce long hairs.

Skull. ( Fig. 10 ) Dorsal view. Rostrum is narrow, laterally flattened. Anterior borders of the nasals are rounded. Posterior borders of the nasals are irregularly square shaped; placed behind both premaxillary-maxillary-frontal and maxillary-frontal-lacrimal joints. Sutures between maxillary and frontal bones are large and numerous. Zygomatic notch is shallow and encloses partially the lacrimal foramen. Lacrimals are rounded; one-half is on the frontal and other in the zygomatic. Interorbital beads are poorly developed. Flanks of interparietal are not projected.

Lateral view. Skull profile is slightly convex. Rostrum presents a small hump. Gnathic anterior process is short. The most anterior part of the suture between nasal and premaxillary bones passes the squamosal root of zygomatic. Breadth of the maxillary root of zygomatic is as M3 length. Zygomatic plate breadth is subequal to the upper molar row length. Squamosal zygomatic root breadth is one-half of the zygomatic plate breadth. Ethmoid foramen is placed among the metacone of M1 to mesoloph of M2. Sphenopalatine foramen is placed at metacone of M2 level; its diameter is subequal or slightly greater than M3 length. Ethmoturbinals breadth is as M1 length. Alisphenoid strut is always absent. Tegmen tympani do not overlap the posterior process of the squamosal. Orbicular apophysis of the malleus is globose and elongate; the lamina is rectangle and shallow. Processus brevis of the incus is large, subequal to incus breadth. Internal surface of mastoid tubercle is concave. Upper border of postglenoid foramen is rounded, at subsquamosal foramen level is tapering; both foramina reach the upper border of the mastoid. Hamular process is narrow, as the orbicular apophysis breadth. Mastoid perforation is placed on the posterior border, similar to M3 length, and square shaped.

Ventral view. Inner borders of the incisive foramina borders are posteriorly convergent. Incisive foramina breadth is about as M1-M2 length. Septum of incisive foramina is narrow. Diastema is flat with a small and elongated hump, placed behind of the premaxillary-maxillary suture. Origin of the superficial masseter is ovoid and slightly protruded; it is placed behind of the anterior border of the zygomatic plate. Maxillary-palatine suture is at hypoflexus level of M1. Posterior palatine foramina are at the hypocone level of M1. Posterolateral palatal pits are placed anterior to the mesopterygoid border level. Sphenopalatine vacuities are open around basisphenoid and presphenoid. Presphenoid is laterally compressed with concave lateral borders. Mesopterygoid fossa breadth is lesser than the incisive foramina breadth. Parapterygoid processes are parallel; laterally, they pass the molar surface level. Borders of the pterygoid plate are convex. Fontanellae are tiny but distinguishable. The posterior opening of the alisphenoid canal breadth is as M3 length. Groove of the infraorbital branch of the stapedial artery is shallow.

Middle lacerate foramina width is as M3 length. Eustachian tube is short and broad. Bullae are flask-shaped. Anterior bulla process and the pterygoid plate are not in contact. Basioccipital breadth at petrosal level is subequal to breadth between second upper molars. Basioccipital pits are shallow. Anterior border of the foramen magnum is obtuse V-shaped with a moderate notch.

Jaw. Masseteric crest is below the procingulum of the m1. Mental foramen is at the labial border of the diastema. Capsular process is moderately developed but does not pass the condylar process. Coronoid process is slightly thin. Condylar process is large and thin. Angular process is short. Crest between condylar and angular process is rounded and shallow. Ventral border of the jaw is concave.

Teeth. Upper. Incisors are opisthodont, with rounded tips and yellow-orange enamel bands. Molar rows are parallel. Procingulum of M1 is anteriorly flattened, narrow and symmetrically divided. Anteroflexus of M1 does not reach the labial surface. Mesoloph of M1 is antero-posteriorly convex and does not reach the labial surface. Posteroloph of M1 does not reach to the labial surface; posterior border is convex. Anteroloph of M2 is broad and reaches the labial surface. Protoflexus of M2 is deep. Mesoloph of M2 is antero-posteriorly convex to the labial surface. Posteroloph of M2 reaches the molar surface. Posterior border of the posteroloph of M2 is rounded. Anteroloph of M3 reaches the paracone surface. Lower. Procingulum of m1 is symmetrically divided. Mesolophid of m1 is narrow. Hypoflexid of m1 is perpendicular to the labial surface. Posterior border of the posterolophid of m1 is straight, and does not reach the lingual surface. Anterolabial cingulum of m2 is narrow. Posterior border of posterolophid of m2 straight and does not reach the lingual surface.

Remarks. Thomas (1901) reported this species from Inambari River ( Peru ) to Mapiri and Perené rivers ( Bolivia ), but not specified additional information.
Pacheco et al. (2011)
recorded populations of
N. vargasllosai
sp. nov. as
N. spinosus in Challohuma
( 1200 m ) and Yanacocha ( 1985 m ); both localities present yields of citrus fruits, and are placed in the vicinities of the Parque Nacional Bahuaja Sonene ( Peru ). Adult males with scrotal testis were found from 9 to 21 May 2010 . In the same period, female specimens with perforated and non-perforated vagina were found, but none pregnant or lactating. There is not additional information about the biology of this species.

subSection.paragraph:
Undoubtedly the diversity of
Neacomys
is still far from being completely known. Although we have confirmed that
Neacomys spinosus
s.l. is a complex of species, which some of them presented available names in the synonym of the genus (
N. amoenus
s.l. ) and one of them has been described in this study as a new species (
N. vargasllosai
sp. nov. ); based on the phylogenetic reconstruction and the genetic distances ( Fig. 5 ) we conclude that there still are candidate species pending of taxonomic revision and naming (e.g.
Neacomys
sp. “clade 3”,
Neacomys
sp. “clade 6”, and
Neacomys
sp. “clade 7”). The results presented here, including detailed morphological descriptions and phylogenetic support, will contribute to resolving the taxonomy of
Neacomys
.

The morphological and molecular differentiation between
N. spinosus
,
N. amoenus amoenus
, and
N. a. carceleni
recorded here allows for the delimitation of these taxa, as well as for the distinction of
N. vargasllosai
sp. nov. from those taxa ( Table 1 , Fig. 1 -4, Systematics section). Morphological qualitative analysis showed that these rodents can be easily distinguished from each other, that is important to encourage revisions of those Oryzomyini taxa which are spuriously known as cosmopolitan or wide ranged species, such as
Oecomys bicolor (Tomes, 1860)
,
Nectomys rattus Pelzeln, 1883
or
Oligoryzomys microtis (J. A. Allen, 1916)
( Carleton & Musser 2015 ; Bonvicino & Weksler 2015; Weksler & Bonvicino 2015b , respectively). Regarding the molecular analysis, surprisingly we found that any of the sequences previously labeled as “
spinosus
” were actually
N. spinosus
s.s. The haplotype here recorded of
N. spinosus
s.s. (from the vicinities of the type locality) is the first and unique sequence published ( MUSM 36924, KX258228 ), specimen that is morphometric and morphological supported as “
spinosus
” (see Fig. 4, Appendix I and II), thus we provide a plate supplementary plate of this specimen (Fig. S1); additionally we corroborated that this specimen of
N. spinosus
s.s. differs morphologically from two specimens recorded at northern
Amazonas department
(locality 27 in the map, see appendix II for details), which are haplotypes allocated to
N. amoenus
s.l. and morphologically recognized as
N. a. carceleni
( EU579504 and KX792049 ). Thus, we suggest including this taxonomic update in such studies that invoked “
spinosus
”, both in their results and discussions based on molecular evidence of cytochrome b gene (e.g.
Patton et al. 2000
;
Rinehart et al. 2005
; Catzeflis & Tilak 2009 ;
Machado et al. 2014
; da Silva et al. 2015). In reality, those sequences formerly labeled as “
spinosus
” correspond to
N. amoenus
s.l. ( Fig. 5 , Appendix II). Similarly, sequences of "
spinosus
" reported by Weksler (2006) were mostly
N. a. carceleni
.

collapse in a single clade), introgression, migration, divergent sorting, or sympatry. Consequently, the genetic and morphological differentiation within
N. amoenus
s.l. might be assessed in phylogeographic and morphological frame in the future, in order to clarify whether the four clades are full species or there is geographical structure among clades.

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 5. Cladogram of the resulting tree from the Bayesian Inference analysis (Maximum Likelihood analysis provided a congruent topology). Numbers indicate Maximum Likelihood bootstrap values in black (BS, left of the diagonal) and Bayesian posterior probabilities in blue (PP, right of the diagonal). Asterisks indicate BS <50% and PP <0.5. Abbreviations BO: Bolivia, BR: Brazil, CO: Colombia, EC: Ecuador, FG: French Guyana, GU: Guyana, PE: Peru, and SU: Suriname.

FIGURE 6. Illustration map showing the distribution of
N. spinosus
(light blue),
N. a. amoenus
(blue),
N. a. carceleni
(dark purple),
N. amoenus
“CAA” (white) and
Neacomys vargasllosai
sp. nov. (yellow). Diamonds indicate Type Localities, triangles indicate samples of DNA sequences; squares indicate morphologically revised specimens (qualitative and /or quantitatively); and circles indicate both molecular and morphological evidence. See Appendix I for locality numbers.

subSection.paragraph:
The “
tenuipes
” group is a polytomy formed by five species and three candidate species.
N. tenuipes
is close related to Amazonian species, as was proposed by
Patton et al. (2000)
; this species is represented by a single haplotype of 177 bp (see
Patton et al. 2000
for sequencing details), even when this sequence is different enough, we suggest to add larger haplotypes in order to improve the phylogenetic relationships within the group. The Guianese species
N. guianae
is sister group of the candidate species
Neacomys
sp. “clade 6”, which is distributed in the Amazon State of Brazil (
Patton et al. 2000
; Catzeflis & Tilak 2009 ); this species has been differentiated molecularly before (
Patton et al. 2000
; Catzeflis & Tilak 2009 ), but is still pending of morphological revision and naming. The other Guianese species
N. dubosti
is sister group of the candidate species
Neacomys
sp. “clade 7”, distributed in the Pará State of Brazil (
Patton et al. 2000
; da Silva et al. 2015); this species have been differentiated molecular and cytogenetically and is currently in description (da Silva et al. 2015).
Neacomys
sp. “clade 3”, occurs in the Amazonia of Ecuador and northern Peru ; it presents three groups of haplotypes, one from the Ecuadorian population, other from Peruvian population, and only one haplotype from the pre-Andean population ( MVZ 153530).
N. musseri
presents three groups of haplotypes that match with the geographic distribution in the Amazon Basin (haplotypes from Loreto ), Juruá Basin (haplotypes from Acre and Madre de Dios ), and mountain cloud forests (haplotypes from Cusco ).
N. minutus
s.l. is formed by two clades that match with their distribution along the Juruá River “upriver clade” and “downriver clade” (
Patton et al. 2000
). These clades present enough morphometric (multivariate) and molecular (6.9% of genetic divergence) evidence to be considered different species, but need further taxonomic revision (
Patton et al. 2000
). The genetic clustering within
Neacomys
sp. “clade 3”,
N. musseri
, and
N. minutus
might be assessed in a phylogeographic framework.

FIGURE 8. Dorsal, ventral, and lateral views of the cranium and the mandible of

(BMNH 3.7.7.84, holotype).

FIGURE 9. Dorsal, ventral, and lateral views of the cranium and the mandible of

subSection.paragraph:
The biogeographic ranges of the species within “
spinosus
” group are distinct.
Neacomys spinosus
is an endemic species from Peru that inhabits in mountain cloud forests between the southern of Marañon River to the northern of Huallaga River ( Lawrence 1941; this study ).
N. vargasllosai
sp. nov. inhabits in mountain cloud forests between Peru and Bolivia from the northern of the Inambari River to western Santa Cruz ( Thomas 1901 ;
Pacheco et al. 2011
; this study). Likewise,
N. amoenus
s.l occurs in the Cerrado between eastern Bolivia and western Brazil , and the Amazon rainforests from southeastern Ecuador to northeastern Peru . Contrasting with the last record of Peruvian mammals (
Pacheco et al. 2009
), we conclude that at least five species of
Neacomys
are present in Peru (
N. amoenus
,
N. minutus
,
N. musseri
,
N. spinosus
, and
N. vargasllosai
sp. nov. ).

Based on the species’ distributions in the Andes, it is possible that rivers on the eastern slope of the Andes (e.g. Marañón , Huallaga, Apurimac , and Inambari) could have played a role in delimiting the distribution of these species of
Neacomys
. The role of rivers in the diversification of Andean biota has been previously proposed in birds (e.g.
Ribas et al. 2007
; Weir 2009 ; Bonaccorso 2009 ;
Chaves et al. 2011
, Winger & Bates 2015 ), plants (e.g.
Pennington et al. 2010
;
Särkinen et al. 2012
) and rodents ( Patton & Smith 1992 ). In the case of sigmodontine rodents, Patton & Smith (1992) were the precursors assessing the allopatric role of Andean rivers in the diversification of
Akodon
; they recovered reciprocal monophyly between populations without morphological support, suggesting that further taxonomic analysis is needed to support speciation. After the research of Patton & Smith (1992) , recent taxonomic studies invoked the allopatric role of the rivers along the Andes to constrain the distribution of sigmodontine species (e.g. Luna & Pacheco, 2002 ;
Jiménez et al. 2013
;
Pacheco et al. 2014
; Rengifo & Pacheco 2015 ), however some of these studies have failed to use formal methods to assess allopatric speciation or lacks phylogenetic support. In this context, the divergence of
Neacomys
species in the Andes could be due to the allopatric role of the Andean rivers; however, further analysis is needed to assess whether these rivers were preexisting barriers or not.

The origin and diversification of
Neacomys
as other Oryzomyini has been proposed in the lowlands of South America; for instance, Weksler (2006) suggested that
Euryoryzomys
,
Mindomys , Neacomys
,
Oreoryzomys
and
Scolomys
might have originated in western Amazonia and/or in the eastern Andes, based on the phylogenetic relationships and species distributions. Leite et al. (2014) estimated the ancestral area distribution for the most recent common ancestor ( MRCA ) among sigmodontine, concluding that the MRCA of
Neacomys
inhabited eastern South America and the northern Andes. Given that the central Andes was dismissed from Leite et al .’s analysis of
Neacomys
, we suggest that the distribution of the MRCA of
Neacomys
needs to be reanalyzed. Recently,
Parada et al. (2013
, 2015 ) assessed the diversification of sigmodontines using exhaustive taxonomic sampling, and among other remarkable results, they found that the hypothetical ancestor of Oryzomyini as well as of
Neacomys
, could have originated and diversified in the lowlands of South America (e.g. Cerrado, Pampas or Amazonia). Herein, based on the topology of the tree ( Fig. 5 ) we suggest that
Neacomys
could have originated in the lowlands of northwestern South America, where two lineages diverged. One lineage stayed in the Guiana shield (“
paracou
” group); while the second one diversified and then invaded the remaining areas in western and southern South America forming two additional lineages (“
tenuipes
” and “
spinosus
” groups). The lineage of “
spinosus
” group would have diversified in the Central Andes and expanded toward the northern Andes, the Cerrado and western Amazonia (
N. amoenus
s.l. ), while the lineage of “
tenuipes
” group would have diversified in western Amazonia and Northern Andes, and then expanded toward the Central Andes (
N. musseri
) and Guiana shield (
N. guianae
and
N. dubosti
). This biogeographic approach suggests that the Andes were invaded by two different lineages of
Neacomys
(“
tenuipes
” and “
spinosus
” groups), while the Guiana shield was posteriorly invaded by two lineages of the “
tenuipes
” group. It is noted that this hypothesis must be properly tested with the inclusion of
N. pictus
, which could give evidence regarding the historical scenario of
Neacomys
in Central America.

We acknowledge J. L. Patton (Museum of Vertebrate Zoology, University of California , Berkeley) for kindly sharing unpublished sequences with us, B. D. Patterson for supporting N.H. to visit the collections of the Field Museum of Natural History (Chicago), and Grace P. Servat and Terry Erwin for supporting N.H. to visit the collections of the National Museum of Natural History ( Washington DC ). We also thank G. D’Elía (Instituto de Ciencias Ambientales & Evolutivas, Universidad Austral de Chile ) for helping in the DNA sequencing and getting photos of the Holotype of
N. a. carceleni
